Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2013 01:17PM - edited Feb 10, 2013 01:20PM by BaseballFan Yes, LilS....this is the one. And to 4myangels....thanks for adding the "L". In the paperwork I was given, one time there is an "L" and one time they left out the "L"....naturally that's what I copied...What the "L" is that all about? Sorry...I couldn't resist! That's the closest I ever get to swearing! Anyway....MPDL3280A is a human monoclonal antibody made in a lab. Using MPDL is based on the idea of helping the body 's own natural ability to defend itself by attaching to a molecule called Programmed Death Ligand-1 (PD-L1). PDL1 is one of many switches that help control T cell activity to keep them from attacking normal tissues. Some cancers avoid being killed by T cells by expressing PD-L1 on their surface and turning off the T cells trying to attack the tumor. This might allow the T cells to more effectively attack tumors. So, MPDL3280 A is being studied as a way to make T cells more active against Tumors. There are 20 centers participating. Breast cancer is definitely one of the cancers being studied.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 09:16AM BaseballFan wrote: Well, I just got off the phone with a rep from the Kansius Foundation.  She was extremely helpful and willing to talk.  SPREADING THE WAVE is an informational promotion designed to get the word out about this new machine.  The WAVE is holding 6 town hall meetings in Florida because the inventor lived in Sanibel Island.  A machine is currently being built in Erie PA with the hope that it will be ready for initial trial in the spring.  Smaller machines have already been tested with great success and they are CONFIDENT that the large machine will produce the same results.  If that is the case, they anticipate human trials to begin within 2 years.  When I asked about media response (they were on 60 minutes two times in the past), she said they are continually alerting media of their progress but feel the media is waiting for the larger machine to be finished.  They have also contacted Oprah to try to get on during her last year....but so does everyone else. If the town hall meetings go well, they hope to do the same in other major markets.  She indicated that major hospitals are incredibly eager to get going with this new technology also. Its a frustratingly slow process...when we want it to happen now.  But once again....there are brilliant people out there who want this to work....not for the money.....but for you, me and their own loved ones.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 10:11PM BaseballFan wrote: Honest to gosh....I have NO side effects at all! I am on my 4th cycle and plan on another cycle before starting a breast cancer vaccine trial.  I realize I might be very lucky....but I haven't had one thing!  When the onc prescribed Xeloda, they went over everything and gave me some "Udder Cream" samples, which I have used on my feet and hands, but no sign of hand/foot problems.  Onc also prescribed medication for nausea and I assumed since they were handing it to me, nausea was inevitable.  So I'd take an "as needed" pill with my doses and must admit I was pretty tired......until I realized the anti-nausea pill was causing the problem.  Once I stopped that, my fatigue totally disappeared. Here's hoping you are SE free!

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 11:13PM - edited Oct 28, 2012 11:16PM by BaseballFan So....I went to the Kanzius conference in Erie. It was definitely worth the time and money and my friend and I are definitely going to attend next year. I learned so much....here are some bullet points of things I already knew or learned. - There are a lot of VERY smart people out there...and they want to cure cancer. Dr. Curley said, "I can help 100 people, but it's the one I can't help is the one that keeps me up at night." - Medical presentations were made by three doctors: Dr. Curley (MDA), Dr. Hong Koo Kim, University of Pittsburgh Medical,Center, and Dr. Dustin Kruse, University of California, Davis. - John Kanzius (Erie PA resident, radio engineer and cancer patient) had a theory that a machine could heat cancer cells and destroy them without harming healthy cells. Seems complicated but in reality it is not. - The Kanzius machine can be compared to TV remotes, cell phones, garage door openers...anything that uses radio waves. - These radio waves, at the proper frequencies, can heat metal. If this metal is placed inside a cancer cell and heated, the cancer cell only is destroyed. - Researchers have put this to the test using microscopic metals called nano particles and put them in the patient's bloodstream. This takes about 45 seconds. These particles combine with antibodies and then target and attach themselves to cancer cells. The Kanzius machines generates enough heat to destroy the cancer....with NO side effects. - Researchers have been able to kill cancer cells 100% of the time in small animals. In the last five months the same testing has been conducted on pigs and results are the same. Studies are ongoing and must be validated prior to going to the FDA. They are optimistic that Phase I trials will begin in 2013 at MDA. - Dr. Curley indicated that approximately 15 patients will participate in Phase I so Phase II will follow soon. Those trials will be performed in Erie per John Kanzius' request. - They know it works. What still needs to be determined is what the frequency should be. - They know every cancer is unique so research is ongoing. - They are starting trials with cancers of the pancreas and liver and then will branch out to include other cancers with HER2 positive being a priority. The hope is that as they learn more each day and begin to cure the cancers, the other research will develop much quicker with each success. The video they showed, along with Dr. Curley's presentation, was so inspiring. He truly believes this will be the cure to cancer. But the person who quieted the room was Toni. She has been Stage IV with breast cancer for 6 1/2 years. You know the routine....surgery, meds, 6 different chemo regimens.....and terrible side effects. She did a great job and I hope she sees this post. So....will the cure be tomorrow? No. But I truly believe they are close. Bobbi
